author: A. B. Curtisa
summary: The author advocates for a federal guarantee of bank deposits to address the currency and banking emergency. They propose that local banks within the Cleveland Clearing House Association temporarily guarantee each other's credits until federal legislation can be enacted to nationalize the banking industry. Additionally, they suggest recognition of the right to convert savings into commercial accounts and raise the idea of a uniform international currency and banking system.
text:
URGES FEDERAL GUARANTEE OF BANK DEPOSITS <<<<<<< HEAD

To the Editor of The Press The present currency and banking emergency emphasizes the necessity of the speedy enactment of legislation by Congress completely to nationalise the banking industry, the federal government guaranteeing all bank deposits and undertaking to issue legal tender for them upon demand. In the meantime, to meet, partially, at least, our local demands, the member banks of the Cleveland Clearing House Association should at once agree between themselves jointly to guarantee the credits of each to the other, to the end for instance, that I could deposit a check from a client drawn on the Cleveland Trust Co, to my checking account with the Guardian, enabling me to draw checks, against my credit to my grocer and coal dealer, for deposit by them in the Union Trust Co., the Central United National Bank, etc. Incidentally, the right to convert savings into commercial accounts should be recognized. I can understand the necessity of limitations upon the withdrawal of currency, but not upon the transfer of creditors. If I cared to pursue the subject further, I could raise the question of the feasibility of a uniform international currency and banking system, looking to the joint guarantee by all civilized nations of the currency, if not the bank credits of each. A. B. Curtisa 241 Euclid ayenue,
title: Urges Federal Guarantee Of Bank Deposits <<<<<<< Head

author: F. H. Mueller
summary: The author, a former Cincinnatian and participant in the city's current government launch, defends Cincinnati against the editorial claim that it doesn't go far enough. He praises Cincinnati's efficient waste collection system, reliable fire and police services, superior school system with a municipal university, lower tax rate with excellent public services, and an impressive library collection for the blind. Criticizing Cleveland's manager form of government for its large council susceptible to party manipulation, he highlights Cincinnati's small council elected at large and well-paid members. The letter also addresses the quality of citizens in each city, attributing Cincinnati's desirability to its third-generation German, Irish, and northern Italian ancestry.
text:
HE LIKES CINCINNATI

To the Editor of The Press Your editorial about Cincinnati was very good except that you do not go far enough. As a former Cincinnatian, and one who had a very small part in launching the present city government, think you could also have mentioned the following points. In spite of economical operation, Cincinnati has a police and fire department which will bear comparison with the best in the country, Their waste collection system is thorough and reliable, not the hit or miss proposition it is here. The school system is one of the best in the country, while the city maintains a municipal university which attracts students from all over the world. All these services, besides many others of a more distinctive character, are provided for out of a tax rate considerably lower than that of Cleveland. Just to mention one of the distinctive Cincinnati projects, I recall an item in one of the papers recently mentioning the fact that the Cincinnati Public Library had the best collection of Braille books for the blind in the United States throughout the country. In my judgment Cleveland doomed its manager form of government to failure from the start by the retention of the large, locally elected council, poorly paid and therefore open to party manipulation. Cincinnati only has nine councilmen, elected at large and paid well enough to make them less susceptible to influence from selfishly motivated interests. But the greatest difference, and one that only time can change is the fundamental difference in the electorate. This city, together with Detroit, Chicago and others is now paying the price for the senseless drive for mere size regardless of the quality of the people who made up the increase it will take this city a generation and possibly two to develope a citizenship averaging up with the third generation German, Irish and northern Italian stock to which most Cincinnatians can trace their ancestry. I have no desire to minimize the good points of Cleveland which are numerous and real but as they stand at present Cleveland may be twice as big, but Cincinnati is twice as desirable a city in which to live. F. H. Mueller, 12623 Iowa avenue, N.
title: He Likes Cincinnati

entities.name: Cincinnati

entities.name: Cleveland
entities.identity: City referenced in the letter as having a large council open to manipulation; mentioned in comparison to Cincinnati.

entities.name: F. H. Mueller

author: J. J. Zwalsh
summary: The letter suggests that the government should mandate all money to be stamped with a government seal through the controller's hands, making it obsolete and worthless after a specified period to prevent runs on banks and hoarding of money.
text:
JACKRABBIT MONEY

To the Editor of The Press Why does not the government issue a statement to the effect that all money must be put through the controller's hands and be stamped with the government seal and that unless this is done the money would become obsolete and worthless after 30 days or such given time. This would prevent a run on the banks and stop hoarding of money. J. J. Zwalsh. 5920 St. Clair avenue,
title: Jackrabbit Money

entities.identity: Federal government of the United States

entities.identity: Government official responsible for currency control.

entities.identity: Street in Cleveland, Ohio

author: C. B. Keenum
summary: The author argues that the U.S. should print $40 billion in currency to balance the budget and reduce interest rates, thus saving the people $8 billion annually. This move would increase buying power and stimulate prosperity more effectively than current public works, beer tax, or foreign trade programs.
text:
WANTS MORE CURRENCY

To the Editor of The Press This bank limitation of 5 per cent on withdrawals that has just reached Cleveland reminds one of the recent statement made by Secretary Mills that the total bank deposits in the U.S.A amounts to $46,000,000,000 and the actual cash in the U.S.A. amounts to less than $6,000,000,000. If our Congress would now print $40,000,000,000 in currency there would then be just enough money in the country to cover the bank deposits and if our government should print $40,000,000,000 on its own instead of the usual "bank notes" and loan the same to refinance farm and home loans at 2 per cent interest, the revenue to the government would almost balance the budget and, at the same time force down all interest rates to 2 per cent and this save a difference in interest burden on the American people of 4 per cent average on the 200,000,000,000 total of interest bearing debts, or $8,000,000,000. This $8,000,000,000 a year saving to the people would automatically increase the buying power of the masses to that extent. It would do more to "restore confidence" and create prosperity than all the public works programs and beer tax programs and foreign trade programs all put together could do. Let's put Cleveland to work but not by inflating our debt structure with more bond issues. Our banker friends are hollering their heads off Against inflation of currency, but you don't hear one of them saying a word about us having inflated our debts so much that just the interest now amounts to 4,000,000 a year more than our entire money supply. For us to try and run this country with less than $6,000,000,000 (plus bank credit confidence) is like trying to run a motor car with one pint of oil in the crank case. C. B. Keenum, 2244 E. Ninth street.
title: Wants More Currency

author: Philip Garbo
summary: The letter challenges Rabbi Brickner's radio comments about Hitler's rise to power and his views on Mussolini's Italy, arguing that Von Hindenburg cannot be that powerless and asserting that Mussolini has maintained peace despite France's provocations. The author also questions Rabbi Brickner's comparison of Hitler with Mussolini and argues that if such an expulsion of Jews were to occur, Mussolini would welcome them in Italy. Additionally, the letter disputes the idea of an impending war between Germany, Italy, Austria, Hungary, and their adversaries.
text:
DIFFERS WITH RABBI BRICKNER

To the Editor of The Press Rabbi Brickner recently made some remarks on the radio about t which I wish to comment and in some instances take exception to. He said that Hitler has become chancellor because Von Hindenburg is old and his days are numbered. Does the rabbi mean that 60,000,000 people in Germany are asleep that they allow this man to take advantage of them? Certainly Von Hindenburg cannot have lost control of his mind. In one breath he expresses concern about the March 5 elections and that Hitler will drive the Jews from Germany and in the next, the rabbi likens Hitler to Mussolini How can he make such a comparison when it is common knowledge that in the years Mussolini has been in power, the Jews in Italy have received better treatment and more consideration than in any other country in the world. Should such a thing happen in Germany as the driving out of the Jews, an appeal can be made to Mussolini and the Pope and they will welcome the Jews to Italy. He said that Germany, Italy, Austria and Hungary are banding together against France, Yugoslavia and Russia (with Poland on the fence) and that there will soon be war. This is just a bad dream. Mussolini has been in power for more than 10 years and in spite of France's innuendos he has kept and is keeping peace. has been on the fields of battle, wounded several times and he knows what war means. Of course, it is evident that the rabbi is against Mussolini because he is a dictator. He does not tell his listeners of the good that Mussolini has done for Italy, bringing it to its rightful place as a sovereign nation. Think how much better off we would be were Roosevelt vested with the powers of a dictator. Then the kind of corruption in government we read about in Liberty magazine would be rectified. Philip Garbo ======= Letters to the Editor

To the Editer of The Presst, The present currency and banking emergency emphasizes the necessity of the speedy enactment of legislation by Congress completely to nationalize the banking industry, the federal government guaranteeing all bank deposits and undertaking to issue legal tender for them upon demand.

In the meantime, to meet, partially, at least, our local demands, the member banks of the Cleveland Clearing House Association should at once agree between themselves jointly to guarantee the credits of each to the other, to the end, for instance, that I could deposit a check from a client drawn on the Cleveland Trust Co. to my checking account with the Guardian, enabling me to draw checks, against my credit to my grocer and coal dealer, for deposit by them in the Union Trust Co., the Central United National Bank, etc. Incidentally, the right to convert savings into commercial accounts should be recognized.

I can understand the necessity of limitations upon the withdrawal of currency, but not upon the transfer of creditors.

If I cared to pursue the subject further, I could raise the question of the feasibility of, a uniform-international currency and banking system, looking to the joint guarantee by all civilized nations of the currency, if not the bank credits of each. A. B. Curtiss 241 Euclid avenue.
title: Differs With Rabbi Brickner

author: F. H. Mueller
summary: The author praises Cincinnati for its effective government services, particularly its police and fire departments, reliable waste collection system, excellent school system, and the maintenance of a municipal university. They criticize Cleveland's government form by retaining a large, locally elected council open to party manipulation. They claim that the fundamental difference in the electorate has led to a lesser quality of citizenship in Cleveland compared to Cincinnati. Finally, the author expresses their personal preference for living in Cincinnati due to its desirable qualities and cites the library's Braille book collection as an example of Cincinnati's civic excellence.
text:
HE LIKES CINCINNATI

 To the Editor of The Press! Your editorial about Cincinnati was very good except that you do not go far enough..

As a former Cincinnatian, and one who had a very small part in launching the present city government, think you could also have mentioned the following points. In spite of economical operation, Cincinnati has a police and fire department which will bear comparison with the best in the country. Their waste collection system is thorough and reliable, not the hit or miss proposition it is here. The school system is one of the best in the country, while the city maintains a municipal university which attracts students from all over the world.

All these services, besides many others of a more distinctive character, are provided for out of a tax rate considerably lower than that of Cleveland. Just to mention one of the distinctive Cincinnati projects. I recall an item in one of the papers recently mentioning the fact that the Cincinnati Public Library had the best collection of Braille books for the blind in the United States and that it was extensively used throughout the country.

In my judgment Cleveland doomed its manager form of government to failure from the start by the retention of the large, locally elected, council, poorly paid and therefore open to party manipulation. Cincinnati only has nine councilmen, elected at large and paid well enough to make them less susceptible to influence from selfishly motivated interests.

But the greatest difference, and one that only time can change is the fundamental difference in the electorate. This city, together with Detroit, Chicago and others is nowpaying the price for the senseless b -drive for mere size regardless of the quality of the people who made up the increase, It will take this city a generation and possibly two to s develope a citizenship averaging up with the third generation German, a Irish and northern Italian stock to which most Cincinnatians can trace their ancestry. I have no desire to minimize the good points of Cleveland which are humerous and real but as they stand at present Cleveland may be twice as big, but Cincinnati is twice as desirable a city in which to live. F. H. Mueller, 12623 Iowa avenue, N. E.
title: He Likes Cincinnati

entities.identity: The writer of the letter.
Mentioned in relation to Cincinnati's tax rate comparison. Likely refers to Cleveland, Ohio, due to the context of discussing city management and services in comparison.
Refers to the city council in Cleveland. Mentioned as a factor in the failure of the manager form of government in Cleveland.
The composition of Cincinnati's city council, suggesting a more centralized and less prone to local influences than Cleveland's council.
Cincinnati's institution for higher education, positioned as an attraction for international students and noted for its collection of Braille books.

text:
JACKRABBIT MONEY

To the Editor of The Press: Why does not the government issue a statement to the effect that all money must be put through the controller's hands and be stamped with the government seal and that unless this is done the money would become obsolete and worthless after 30 days or such given time. This would prevent a run on the banks and stop hoarding of money. J. J. Zwalsh, 5920 St. Clair avenue.

author: C. B. Keenum
summary: The author argues that the U.S. government should print $40 billion in currency to address the disparity between bank deposits and actual cash, refinancing farm and home loans at low interest rates to alleviate the national debt burden, increase buying power, and stimulate the economy. The letter criticizes the current financial practices and policies for creating an imbalance that threatens the economic stability of the country.
text:
WANTS MORE CURRENCY

To the Editor of The Pres This bank limitation of 5 per cent on withdrawals that has just reached Cleveland reminds one of the recent statement made by Secretary Mills that the total bank deposits in the U; S. A. amounts to $46,000,000,000 and the actual cash in the U. S. A. amounts to less than $6,000,000,000. If our Congress would now print $40,000,000,000 in currency there would then be just enough money in the country to cover the bank deposits and if our government should print $40,000,000,000 on its own instead of the usual "bank notes" and loan the same to refinance farm and home loans at 2 per cent interest, the revenue to the government would almost balance the budget and, at the same time force down all interest rates to 2 per cent and thus save a difference in interest burden on the American people of 4 per cent average on the-200,000,000,000 total of interest bearing debts, or $8,000,000,000. This $8,000,000,000 a year saving to the people would automatically increase the buying power of the masses to that extent. It would do more to "restore confidence" and create prosperity than all the public works programs and beer tax programs and foreign trade programs all put together could do. Let's put Cleveland to work but not by inflating our deht structure with more bond issues. Our banker friends are hollering their heads off against "inflation of currency," but you don't hear one of them saying a word about us having inflated our debts so much that just the interest now amounts to 4,000,000 a year more than our entire money supply. For us to try and run this country with less than $6,000,000,000 (plus bank credit confidence) is like trying to run a motor car with one pint of oil in the crank case.. C. B. Keenum, 2244 E. Ninth street.
title: Wants More Currency

author: Philip Garbo
summary: The author, Philip Garbo, disputes Rabbi Brickner's radio remarks about Hitler becoming chancellor and makes several points challenging the rabbi's views. Garbo questions how 60 million Germans could allow Hitler to come to power, asserts that Hindenburg is not out of control, criticizes Rabbi Brickner's comparison of Hitler to Mussolini given Italy's treatment of Jews, disputes Rabbi Brickner's prediction of an imminent war involving Germany, Italy, Austria, Hungary against France, Yugoslavia, and Russia with Poland on the fence, and argues that Mussolini has maintained peace and brought good to Italy under his dictatorship. Garbo implies that a dictatorial power similar to Mussolini could have resolved the corruption issues mentioned in Liberty magazine if President Roosevelt had such powers.
text:
DIFFERS WITH RABBI BRICKNER

 To the Editor of The Prese: p Rabbi Brickner recently made w some remarks on the radio about t which I wish to comment and in M some instances take exception to. He said that Hitler has become. H chancellor because Von Hindenburg is old and his days are numbered. Does the rabbi mean that 60,000,000 people in Germany are asleep that they allow this man to take advantage of them? Certainly Von Hindenburg cannot have lost control of his mind. In one breath he expresses .concern about the March 5 elections and that Hitler will drive the Jews from Germany and in the next, the rabbi likens Hitler to Mussolini How can he make such a comparison when it is common knowledge that in the years Mussolini has been in power, the Jews in Italy have received better treatment and more consideration than in any other country in the world. Should such a thing happen in Germany as the driving out of the Jews, an appeal can be made to Mussolini and the Pope and they will welcome the Jews to Italy. S G F He said that Germany, Italy, Austria and Hungary are banding together against France, Jugoslavia and Russia (with Poland on the c fence) and that there will soon be war. This is just a bad dream. Mussolini has been in power for more than 10 years and in spite of France's inuendos he has kept and is keeping peace. He has been on the fields of battle, wounded several times and he knows what war means.. Of course, it is evident that the rabbi is against Mussolini because he is a dictator. He does not telle his listeners of the good that Mussolini has done for Italy, bringing it to its rightful place as a sovereign nation. Think how much better off we would be were Roosevelt vested with the powers of a dictator. Then the kind of corruption in government we read about In Liberty magazine would be rectified. Philip Garbo >>>>>>> 1157991 (Extract text with new method)
title: Differs With Rabbi Brickner
